item.title: Programs for fast access via terminal and my fasd configuration
item.description: Introduction If you ever find yourself in a repetitive process of cd to another directory you have ever used, there is a family of programs you should learn of. The z, autojump, v, fasd and zoxide terminal programs stores recently visited directories and files that you can cd into, open them with $EDITOR or xdg-open and use them as arguments to another commands (mv, cp etc). Next I will tell you about the differences and features of each one.

item.title: My terminal tricks for everyday usage
item.description: My terminal tricks In the previous post I wrote how to master the terminal, now I can show a few tricks I use to simplify everyday programming life. History command You can count what commands you type the most frequently and then rewrite them or relearn not to type them at all. You can see the commands using this command: history -n | sort | uniq -c | sort -n | tail -5

item.title: Terminal productivity advices
item.description: I’d like to show some of my terminal tricks that can boost your productivity in both everyday programming and related stuff. However, I’ll do it in the next blogpost, since they are just examples of how to combine basic terminal skills, so firstly I should describe skills that helps me to develop the workflow suited for my everyday usage. I try to sort the skills from most important to less.
